bioghist.p: The Philadelphia Public Ledger was published from March 25, 1836 to January 1942. Founded by William M. Swain, Arunah S. Abell, and Azariah H. Simmons, and edited by Swain, it was the first penny paper in Philadelphia. In 1864, it was sold to George William Childs and Anthony J. Drexel. In 1902, New York Times owner Adolph Ochs bought the paper, merged in the Philadelphia Times (which he had bought the previous year), and installed his brother George as editor. In 1913, Cyrus Curtis purchased the paper, launching an evening edition in 1914. On April 16, 1934, the morning and Sunday editions were merged into The Philadelphia Inquirer (also held by the heirs of Curtis), but the paper continued an independent life as the Evening Public Ledger. In 1941, the Evening Public Ledger was sold to Robert Cresswell, formerly of the New York Herald Tribune. Mounting debts brought on a court-ordered liquidation, and the paper ceased publication in January, 1942.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of correspondence and business records of the Evening Public Ledger. The correspondence largely relates to circulation and subscriptions and there is some correspondence with advertisers. There is also a series of letters from a family whose daughter may have been harassed by a Ledger delivery driver. The collection includes several publicity photographs.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
